strings.string: Alarmz displays alarms at the date and time you specify with customized text. Browse these help files to find out what you can do with Alarmz.

When you close Alarmz's main window, the program keeps running in the background. An icon appears in the notification area (system tray, usually near the clock). Double-click it to make the main window reappear or right-click it for more options. See a description of the context menu options in the Menus topic.
Here is a description of Alarmz's menus.
Closes the open window (after save prompt) and creates a new file.
Saves the alarms file under its current name. If the file has not been saved yet, the Save As command is run.
Saves the alarms file under a new name.
Closes the window but keeps showing alarms.
Exits Alarmz. Alarms will not be shown anymore.
Creates an exact copy of the selected alarm.
When this menu option is checked, alarms will show up at the requested times.
Shows the window hidden by File/Close Window or the system menu.

To see alarms, there must be at least one alarm in the list. When the system's date and time are "later" than an alarm's date and time, this alarm shows up. If its frequency is None, the alarm is automatically removed from the list. Otherwise, the date is increased by the duration corresponding to the frequency. As soon as an alarm is displayed, the alarms file is modified and you must save it, or the alarms will reappear when you reopen the file. There is an option that makes Alarmz save the alarms file automatically when it is closed or when Alarmz exits.
This window presents the 4 parameters for an alarm.
Type the message to display in the message box or the toast, depending on the option selected in the Display method selector. Certain HTML tags can be used in the message.
Enter the date and time at which the alarm shall be displayed. This value will be updated every time the alarm is shown (unless the frequency is None, in which case the alarm will simply be deleted).
Select the frequency at which the alarm will show up.
None: The alarm will be displayed once at the specified date and time and will then be removed from the list.
Daily: The alarm will be displayed every day at the same time, starting on the specified date.
Weekly: The alarm will be displayed every 7 days at the same time, starting on the specified date.
Monthly: The alarm will be displayed every month on the same day at the same time, starting on the specified date.
Yearly: The alarm will be displayed every year on the same month and day at the same time, starting on the specified date.
Message box - no icon: Displays a message box with no icon.
Message box - error: Displays a message box with the "error" icon.
Message box - question: Displays a message box with the "question" icon.
Message box - exclamation: Displays a message box with the "exclamation" icon.
Message box - information: Displays a message box with the "information" icon.
Toast: Displays a toast. Toasts have the advantage of featuring a Snooze button and not blocking the application.

string.html:p: Toasts are small windows that appear on a side of the screen. Alarmz lets you customize them in the Options window.

In Alarmz, toasts stack up horizontally (from left to right or from right to left) or vertically (top-down or bottom-up). You can specify in which corner of the primary screen the first toast will appear; the corner will determine the sense the toasts will stack up. Furthermore, the direction of the gradient (if enabled) changes according to the direction selected in the options.
When a toast is shown, a sound can be played (see options).

When several toasts are shown at the same time, they stack up away from the corner specified in the options and move closer to that corner when a toast before them is closed. So, to close all open toasts, you can click the Close button on the first toast and keep clicking until there are no more toasts.
Toasts also have the advantage of not blocking the application. You can therefore continue managing your alarms even when a toast is visible.

strings.string: The Snooze button doesn't appear in message boxes. This button lets you hide the alarm to make it show up later (a bit like an alarm clock that turn off the alarm to turn it back on later). You can choose the snooze duration (that is, the time to wait before showing the alarm up again) in the options.
The Options window allows you to configure Alarmz. You can use the system's What's This? feature to get a brief explanation of each option.
Select the language of Alarmz's user interface.
When this option is checked, alarms files are automatically saved when another file is opened or when the application exits.
This section gives you options regarding Alarmz's automatic startup.
Check this to run Alarmz when you log on to your computer. Alarmz will run in the background. This option is currently available only on Windows.
Check this to open the specified file when Alarmz is run at session startup. Type the name of the alarms file to load on session startup, or click the ... button to find the file on your file system.
This section lets you customize toasts.

You can change the colors used in toasts. Check the boxes corresponding to the colors you want to customize, then click on the colored buttons to select a color. If a box isn't checked, the system color is used.
Colors in this column correspond to the primary background color. This color is used to draw solid backgrounds on toasts and buttons.
Colors in this column correspond to the secondary background color. When the Background and Gradient boxes for a particular component are checked, a linear gradient background is drawn.
Colors in this column correspond to the text color.
Colors on this line apply to the toast and the message.
Colors on this line apply to the Snooze button.
Colors on this line apply to the Close button.
When checked, toasts will be resized to fit their contents. When unchecked, toasts will have a fixed size.
When checked, uses the native frame border from the windowing system. When unchecked, removes the native frame from the windowing system and draws an outset border.
Select the corner in which the first toast will be positioned. Toasts are always positioned relatively to the primary screen.
Select whether toasts must stack up horizontally or vertically.
Toasts will appear with no animation.
Toasts will appear at their minimal size and will stretch horizontally or vertically, depending on the Direction option.
Toasts will appear with a fade in effect: they will start completely transparent and will end up completely opaque.

Check this box to play a sound when a toast appears. Type the name of the sound to play, or click the ... button to find the file on your file system. The sound must be in a format supported by the operating system. See Qt's documentation to get the list of supported formats.
The duration in minutes before a toasts reappears since the moment the Snooze button was clicked.
